questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient with treatment-resistant schizophrenia has started on clozapine. What is the appropriate duration and frequency of blood test monitoring for this patient taking clozapine?

options.label: A
options.text: Weekly for 6 months, bi-weekly for 6 months, then monthly.

options.label: B
options.text: Monthly for 6 months, then every 3 months.

options.label: C
options.text: Weekly for 3 months, bi-weekly for 3 months, then monthly.

options.label: D
options.text: Monthly for 1 year, then every 6 months.

questions.correct_answer: A. Weekly for 6 months, bi-weekly for 6 months, then monthly.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of mood swings, manic episodes, and psychotic symptoms for 10 months presents for evaluation. She mentions that her psychotic symptoms occur both during mood episodes and independently. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Diagnosis Key Feature Explanation
Schizoaffective Disorder Psychotic symptoms with mood episodes and outside mood episodes Psychosis is present both during mood episodes and independently
Bipolar I Disorder Manic episodes with mood-congruent psychosis Psychosis restricted to mood episodes only
Schizophrenia Psychosis without mood episodes No significant mood symptoms
Mood disorder with psychotic features Psychosis only during mood episodes Psychosis disappears outside mood episodes

questions.text: A 38-year-old man, a software engineer in a stable five-year relationship, has recently become convinced that his partner is unfaithful. Despite having no evidence, he frequently accuses her, checks her phone, questions her whereabouts, and shows irrational jealousy when she is with friends or colleagues. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old man who has lived a normal life and works as an accountant begins to believe that his wife and children have been replaced by impostors. He is convinced that those he interacts with daily are not his real family, leading to significant anxiety and fear. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old woman who has performed well in her personal and professional life believes her coworkers are whispering about her, hiding her belongings, and sabotaging her work projects. Despite having no evidence, she feels anxious and increasingly isolated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Persecutory (Delusion of persecution)

Believing others are trying to harm them (Option A)

Jealous (Delusion of infidelity or Othello syndrome)

Believing that a lover or partner is unfaithful (Option D)

Erotomanic (Delusion of erotomania or De Clerambault’s syndrome)

Believing that another person (often of higher status) is in love with them (Option C)

Somatic type

Believing he or she has some physical disorder that includes:

  • Delusion of parasitosis (infested with parasites, such as bugs or worms)
  • Delusion of dysmorphophobia (body or appearance is distorted or altered in a negative way)
  • Delusion of halitosis (bad breath)

Grandiose (Delusion of grandeur)

Believing one has exceptional abilities, wealth, or fame (Option B)

Delusion of Guilt

Believing that they are an evil person and have ruined their family

Nihilistic delusion

Deny the existence of their body, mind, loved ones, or the world, claiming they have no intelligence, that parts of their body are absent, or even believing they are dead or that the world has ended

Delusion of Poverty

Believing they are impoverished and that destitution threatens them and their family.

Mixed and unspecified type (Delusion of misidentification)

Delusions that are a combination of types or not described by one of the categories:

  • Capgras syndrome
  • Fregoli syndrome
  • Syndrome of metamorphosis
  • Syndrome of subjective doubles

questions.text: A 28-year-old male with schizophrenia, who has been stable on antipsychotics for years, was recently switched to a higher dose of a first-generation antipsychotic. He then becomes increasingly agitated, develops a high fever, and exhibits severe muscle stiffness, appearing less responsive and confused. The involved receptors and the drug of choice for managing this condition are:
questions.explanation:
Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS)

Description

A rare, potentially fatal consequence of neuroleptic administration.

Mechanism

D2 receptor blocking at:

  • Striatum (muscle rigidity)
  • Hypothalamus (hyperthermia)
  • Spinal nerves (autonomic disturbances)
 

Clinical manifestations

Motor and behavioural

Autonomic symptoms
  • Muscular rigidity (most common)
  • Dystonia
  • Akinesia,
  • Mutism
  • Obtundation
  • Agitation
  • Fever (most common)
  • Diaphoresis
  • Raised pulse and blood pressure
  • Sweating
  • Altered consciousness

Associated conditions

Renal failure and myoglobinuria

Laboratory findings
  • Raised levels of creatinine phosphokinase (CPK) (most common)
  • Leukocytosis (raised WBC)
  • Raised liver enzymes
  • Raised plasma myoglobin

Management

  • Stop the drug (causing symptoms)
  • Supportive care (maintain hydration and other vitals)
  • Skeletal muscle relaxants: Dantrolene sodium (drug of choice)
  • Dopamine agonists: Bromocriptine, Amantadine
  • Second-generation antipsychotics (for restarting the treatment for Schizophrenia).

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a diagnosis of schizophrenia has been on antipsychotic medication for over a decade. Her family has noticed that she has been experiencing involuntary movements for the past few months, including repetitive facial grimacing, lip-smacking, and jerky motions of her arms and legs. What is the drug of choice for treatment of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Tardive dyskinesia

Description

A delayed effect (abnormal involuntary movements) of antipsychotics typically occurs until after 6 months of treatment.

Cause

Supersensitization of dopamine (D) receptors due to prolonged exposure to antipsychotic medications.

Manifestations

Abnormal, involuntary movements such as:

  • Lip smacking
  • Chewing
  • Darting, twisting, and protrusion of the tongue (catching fly)
  • Choreiform hand movements (playing piano)
  • Facial grimacing
  • Finger movements and hand clenching
 

In Severe cases:

  • Torticollis (twisting of neck muscles to one side)
  • Retrocollis (neck extension)
  • Trunk twisting
  • Pelvic thrusting

Management

Prevention: Using antipsychotic medications only when indicated and in the lowest effective doses.

 

Regular monitoring: Patients taking antipsychotics should be regularly assessed for any signs of abnormal movements.

 

Treatment:

  • Reducing antipsychotic drugs (or stop if possible)
  • Switching the medication to clozapine (least EPS-causing) or atypical antipsychotics
  • VMAT (Vesicular Monoamine Transporter type 2) receptor inhibitor:
    • Valbenazine (drug of choice) (Option D)
    • Tetrabenazine- Lesser efficacy, more sedation than Valbenazine (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male diagnosed with schizophrenia was prescribed a new antipsychotic medication two weeks ago to manage his symptoms. Since then, he has experienced intense restlessness, a strong urge to move, and difficulty sitting still. What is the most likely diagnosis for his condition?
questions.explanation:
Akathesia

Definition

A subjective feeling of restlessness, objective signs of restlessness, or both.

Manifestations

Subjective: Patient reports feeling restless

 

Objective: (noticed by others)

  • Anxiety
  • Inability to relax
  • Jitteriness
  • Rocking motion
  • Pacing around
  • Rapid alteration of sitting and standing

Management

  • Reduce the dosage of the current medication.
  • Switch to atypical or low-potency typical antipsychotics.
  • Treat with appropriate medications:
    • Beta-blockers (Propranolol is the drug of choice)
    • Anticholinergics
    • Benzodiazepines
  • Consider changing the neuroleptic if needed.

  • Anxiety
  • Inability to relax
  • Jitteriness
  • Rocking motion
  • Pacing around
  • Rapid alteration of sitting and standing

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with a history of schizophrenia has been on antipsychotic treatment for three years. After being prescribed a new medication, she developed unusual muscle contractions in her neck and jaw within a week, resulting in difficulty controlling her head movements, which often twist to one side. Which pathway is primarily responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Pathway

Extent

Manifestations

Nigrostriatal pathway

(Option C)

A decrease in dopamine leads to abnormal movement symptoms like tremors, rigidity, dystonias, etc.

Mesolimbic pathway

(Option A)

An increase in dopamine levels leads to positive symptoms such as:

  • Delusion
  • Hallucination

Mesocortical pathway

(Option B)

A decrease in dopamine levels leads to negative symptoms such as:

  • Anhedonia (loss of interest)
  • Avolition (loss of will)
  • Affective blunting (inability to express emotions).
  • Asociality (decrease in drive to socialise).
  • Alogia (decrease in verbal communication).
  • Attention deficits
  • Apathy (lack of concern).

Tuberoinfundibular pathway

(Option D)

A decrease in dopamine levels leads to hyperprolactinemia, which manifests as:

  • Decreased libido (sex drive)
  • Decreased sexual dysfunction
  • Galactorrhea and amenorrhea (females)

Pathways

Control

Nigrostriatal pathway

Abnormal movements (dystonia)

Mesolimbic pathway

Positive symptoms

Mesocortical pathway

Negative symptoms

Tuberoinfundibular pathway

Hyperprolactinemia

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy has been exhibiting significant behavioural changes over the past six months, including increased withdrawal, loss of interest in activities, declining academic performance, self-talk, and occasional reports of visual hallucinations. Which factor is most likely associated with a better prognosis in this case?
questions.explanation:
Factors

Good Prognosis

Poor Prognosis

Onset

Acute (within two weeks) or Abrupt (within two days)

Insidious (Option A)

Age of onset

Late

Early

Subtypes

  • Catatonic schizophrenia
  • Paranoid schizophrenia
  • Simple (Worst) schizophrenia
  • Hebephrenic schizophrenia

Gender

Female

Male

Prominent symptoms

Positive symptoms

Negative symptoms (Option B)

Mood symptoms

Present

Absent (Option D)

Family history of Schizophrenia

Absent

Present

Marital status

Married

Unmarried or divorced

Social support

Good

Poor

Premorbid personality disorder

Absent

Present

Career

Employed

Unemployed

Precipitating factors or Stressors

Present (Option C)

Absent

Substance abuse

Absent

Present

Compliance to medication

Compliant

Non-compliant

questions.text: A 32-year-old male with schizophrenia has been non-adherent to oral antipsychotic medication, resulting in multiple relapses. The psychiatrist decides to switch him to a long-acting injectable antipsychotic to improve adherence. Which of the following medications is preferred?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

1st Generation (Typical) LAIs

2nd Generation (Atypical) LAIs

Examples
  • Fluphenazine
  • Haloperidol
  • Flupenthixol
  • Zuclopenthixol
  • Pipotiazine
  • Risperidone (Option D)
  • Paliperidone
  • Aripiprazole
  • Olanzapine

Formulation

Oil-based

Aqueous-based

Absorption rate

Slower

Quicker

Test dose requirement

Often required

Not required

Special note

All drugs are esterified forms of the parent compound except Risperidone, which is encapsulated in polymer microspheres.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman has been having thoughts that her friends are prison escapees plotting against her for the past week. Her parents report that she has been talking to imaginary friends, becoming increasingly withdrawn, suspicious, and agitated over the last two weeks, with poor sleep and appetite. She has no prior psychiatric history. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Disorder

ICD-11 Criteria

DSM-5 Criteria

Schizoaffective Disorder
(Option A)

Symptoms of both schizophrenia and mood disorders for

≥ 1 month

Psychotic symptoms without mood disturbances for ≥ 2 weeks.

Delusional Disorder (Option B)

Delusions present for more than three months.

Delusions are present for at least one month.

Schizophrenia (Option C)

Two or more symptoms (e.g., delusions, hallucinations) present for ≥ one month

Two or more symptoms present for ≥ six months

Schizophrenia requires two or more symptoms, with at least one from delusions, hallucinations, thought disorder, or distortion of self-experience. Additional symptoms include negative symptoms, disorganised behaviour, or psychomotor disturbances.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with treatment-resistant schizophrenia has been on multiple antipsychotic medications without significant improvement in his symptoms. He continues to experience severe hallucinations and delusions. What is the most appropriate next step in his management?

A 52-year-old obese male with type 2 diabetes presents with schizophrenia, primarily showing negative symptoms like social withdrawal and lack of motivation. Which antipsychotic medication is the most appropriate choice for his treatment?
questions.explanation:
High risk of weight gain

Moderate risk of weight gain

Low risk of weight gain

Clozapine

Olanzapine

Chlorpromazine

Iloperidone

Sertindole

Quetiapine

Risperidone

Paliperidone

Amisulpride

Asenapine

Brexpiprazole

Aripiprazole

Cariprazine

Haloperidol

Lumateperone

Lurasidone

Sulpiride

Trifluoperazine

Ziprasidone

questions.text: A 34-year-old female with a diagnosis of schizophrenia has been treated with a low dose of olanzapine for the past three weeks. Despite this treatment, she continues to experience persistent positive symptoms with only minimal improvement, including hallucinations and delusions. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. Increase the dosage of olanzapine

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of auditory hallucinations, paranoid delusions, and disorganised thinking, resulting in difficulty maintaining relationships and functioning at work. Physical and mental status examinations reveal hallucinations and delusions, with no history of mood disorders or substance abuse. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
First Generation Antipsychotics

(Typical)

Second Generation Antipsychotics

(Atypical)

Second Generation Antipsychotics

(Atypical)

D2 receptor antagonist

Partial D2 Agonists

D2/5-HT2A Antagonists
  • Haloperidol (Option D)
  • Fluphenazine (Option A)
  • Perphenazine
  • Chlorpromazine
  • Aripiprazole
  • Brexpiprazole
  • Cariprazine (Option D)
  • Risperidone
  • Olanzapine
  • Quetiapine
  • Ziprasidone
  • Paliperidone
  • Lurasidone
  • Clozapine

Extrapyramidal Side Effects (EPS)
  • Common with first-generation antipsychotics, including symptoms like
    • Acute dystonia - Earliest, can occur within minutes of the injection
    • PseudoParkinsonism - Occurs within days to weeks
    • Akathisia - Occurs within days to weeks
  • Alternatives for management include dose reduction, antiparkinson medications, or switching to medications with lower EPS risk.

Tardive Dyskinesia (TD)
  • Affects 20-30% of patients on long-term first-generation antipsychotics, with higher risk in the elderly and those with cognitive or mood disorders.
  • Prevention strategies include using the lowest effective doses and switching to other medications like Clozapine.

Sedation & Postural hypotension

Especially with low-potency antipsychotics.

Long-term antipsychotic use can elevate prolactin levels, affecting sexual function and potentially leading to osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male is evaluated for his first episode of psychosis. As part of the assessment, the clinician reviews various potential risk factors. Which of the following is not considered a risk factor for developing schizophrenia?
questions.explanation:
Positive factors

Negative factors
  • Acute onset
  • Female sex
  • Living in a developed country
  • Presence of mood symptoms
  • Family history of mood disorder
  • Married
  • Insidious onset
  • Childhood or adolescent onset
  • Poor premorbid functioning
  • Cognitive impairment
  • Absence of mood symptoms
  • Negative symptoms
  • Family History of schizophrenia
  • Single/ separated/ divorced

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with schizophrenia presents with symptoms such as lack of interest, alogia, and diminished facial expressions. Which of the following findings is commonly associated with this type of schizophrenia according to Timothy Crow's classification?
questions.explanation:
Timothy Crow's classification

Type 1

Type 2

Associated with positive symptoms like hallucinations, delusions, and bizarre behaviour (Option A)

Presents with negative symptoms like Alogia, avolition, anhedonia

High dopamine levels (Option C)

Low dopamine levels

Normal ventricles (Option B)

Enlarged ventricles

Good response to medication

Poor response to medication

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is experiencing significant delusions of persecution and often fears that her food is being tampered with. She has auditory hallucinations urging her to remain vigilant and distrustful. While her cognitive abilities seem intact, her emotional reactions are inappropriate. What diagnosis should be considered?
questions.explanation:
Type of Schizophrenia

Characteristics

Paranoid Schizophrenia

  • Characterised by delusions and hallucinations.
  • Individuals may have a fixed belief that others are out to harm them, often leading to mistrust and vigilance.
  • Cognitive functions usually remain intact, while emotional responses may be inappropriate.

Catatonic Schizophrenia

(Option A)

Characterised by three or more of the following symptoms:

  • Motor immobility ( stupor)
  • Excessive,odd movement (stereotypies, or mannerisms)
  • Waxy flexibility (bending like a wax candle)
  • Extreme negativism (resisting instructions or maintaining rigidity)
  • Unusual postures (bizarre posturing, catalepsy)
  • Echolalia or echopraxia (Mimicking speech or movements)

Disorganised (Hebephrenic) Schizophrenia
  • Involves disorganised speech and behavior.
  • Inappropriate emotional responses and poor functioning.
  • Typically associated with a poorer prognosis.

Residual Schizophrenia
  • History of schizophrenia with delusions and hallucinations (in the past 1 year) with lingering negative symptoms but minimal or no positive symptoms at present.
  • No prominent delusions or hallucinations
  • Individuals may exhibit social withdrawal and reduced emotional expression.

Simple Schizophrenia
  • Involves prominent negative symptoms

Undifferentiated Schizophrenia

Diagnosis for patients who do not fit into other categories presenting a mix of symptoms.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman diagnosed with schizophrenia has been increasingly neglecting her personal hygiene and no longer initiates activities she used to do before. She spends most of her time sitting in one place without doing anything productive. Which negative symptom does this describe?

A 30-year-old woman presents with symptoms indicating that her thoughts are not under her control. She states that she cannot think without external influence and frequently feels that someone is interfering in her thinking. Which of Schneider's first-rank symptoms does she display?
questions.explanation:
Category

Symptom

Description

Thought Alienation Phenomenon

Thought Insertion

A belief that others are placing thoughts into the patient’s mind.

Thought Withdrawal

A belief that thoughts are being removed from the patient’s mind.

Thought Broadcasting

A belief that others can know or access the patient’s thoughts.

Made Phenomenon

Made Volition (Option A)

A belief that actions are controlled by an external force.

Made Affect

A belief that external forces are altering the patient's emotions.

Made Impulses

Sudden urges or impulses that are perceived as implanted by others.

Auditory Hallucinations

(Option B)

Voices Arguing/Discussing

The patient hears voices discussing or arguing about them, often in the third person.

Example: The patient hears two voices arguing, one saying, “He’s a failure,” and the other replying, “No, he’s not.”

Voices Commenting

The patient hears a voice providing commentary on their actions, usually in the third person.

Example: While cooking, a patient hears a voice say, “She’s burning the food,” reflecting their actions.

Audible Thoughts

The patient hears their own thoughts spoken aloud by a voice.

Example: A patient thinks, “I need to go to the store,” and immediately hears a voice say the same phrase.

Somatic Passivity

Physical sensations are perceived as imposed by external agents.

Example: A patient feels a burning sensation in their arm and believes it is caused by invisible rays from a satellite.

Delusional Perception
(Option D)

A normal perception is interpreted with a delusional belief

Example: A patient sees a red car parked outside and believes it indicates the police are monitoring them for criminal activity.

questions.text: According to Eugen Bleuler, which of the following symptoms are diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia? Affect disturbances Association disturbances Autism Ambivalence
